dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 78% shortfall in life insurance coverage for millennials—that's a staggering number from New York Life's survey.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A seventy eight percent shortfall in life insurance coverage for millennials-that's a staggering number from New York Life's survey.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennialsanyone born between 1981 and 1996, so ages 22 to 37 this yearreport a 78% shortfall in life insurance coverage, according to the survey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not that they don't want it, right? Brian Madgett from New York Life says it's a prioritization issue, competing with things like big screen TVs or daily coffee.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not that they don't want it, right? Brian Madgett from New York Life says it's a prioritization issue, competing with things like big screen TVs or daily coffee.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its not an issue of Millennials not wanting to get life insurance; its more a prioritization issue, says Brian Madgett, who leads New York Lifes national life sales and its advanced planning group. The concept of taking care of their families and loved ones is in competition with the big screen tv, car and even that daily cup of coffee.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the average coverage they have is only $110,000, but they actually need around $452,000. That's a huge gap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the average coverage they have is only one hundred ten thousand dollars, but they actually need around four hundred fifty two thousand dollars. That's a huge gap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennials with life insurance have an average of $100,000 in life insurance protection in place, enough to cover one fifth (22%) of their self-reported coverage needs of $452,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Gen Xers have a 48% shortfall, which is still significant but not nearly as bad. They report having about $275,000 but needing over half a million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Gen Xers have a forty eight percent shortfall, which is still significant but not nearly as bad. They report having about two hundred seventy five thousand dollars but needing over half a million.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For Gen Xers, the median amount of life insurance coverage they say they have in place is $272,000, while they say they need $525,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Baby Boomers are at a 33% gap—$200,000 versus $300,000 needed. It seems like every generation is underinsured, just to different degrees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Baby Boomers are at a thirty three percent gap-two hundred thousand dollars versus three hundred thousand dollars needed. It seems like every generation is underinsured, just to different degrees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Baby Boomers say they have $190,000 of coverage but need $300,000a 37% shortfall.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Madgett even suggests using holiday gatherings as a chance to talk about this stuff. Like, if a family member nudges you, maybe listen up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Madgett even suggests using holiday gatherings as a chance to talk about this stuff. Like, if a family member nudges you, maybe listen up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Madgett suggests using the life insurance gap data as a conversation starter over the holidays. Listen up when a family member says, Hey, you need to take care of this, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. He mentioned his own dad pushing him and his husband to get term life insurance once they had kids. That's often the trigger—buying a home or starting a family.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. He mentioned his own dad pushing him and his husband to get term life insurance once they had kids. That's often the trigger-buying a home or starting a family.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I remember my dad nudging my husband and me to get term life insurance policies. We finally did when we had kids.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And term life is surprisingly affordable, too. For a healthy 35-year-old, a $500,000 policy might only cost around $250 a year for 20 years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And term life is surprisingly affordable, too. For a healthy thirty five-year-old, a five hundred thousand dollars policy might only cost around two hundred fifty dollars a year for twenty years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For a healthy 35-year-old male, it would cost about $250 a year for a 20-year level term policy with a $500,000 death benefit, according to Term4sale.com, where you can run your own numbers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But workplace policies aren't enough—they only cover maybe one or two years of salary and don't stick with you if you change jobs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But workplace policies aren't enough-they only cover maybe one or two years of salary and don't stick with you if you change jobs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you have life insurance coverage at work, keep in mind that that policy might pay only one- or two-years salary, and it will likely end if you leave your job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so it's worth shopping around. Premiums vary a lot between insurers, and you gotta check their financial strength ratings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so it's worth shopping around. Premiums vary a lot between insurers, and you gotta check their financial strength ratings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Premiums vary greatly for the same product from different insurers, so shop around. And make sure you assess the financial strength of the insurance company before you buy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The American Institute of CPAs has a calculator to help figure out how much coverage you actually need, which is super helpful.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The American Institute of CPAs has a calculator to help figure out how much coverage you actually need, which is super helpful.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The American Institute of CPAs has a life insurance needs calculator to help you determine how much you really need.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Term4sale.com lets you run your own numbers to compare. Locking in younger means lower premiums, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the website lets you run your own numbers to compare. Locking in younger means lower premiums, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buying younger lets you lock in a lower level premium.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's all about making it a priority now rather than later—especially with things like student debt and saving for kids' education already weighing on millennials.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's all about making it a priority now rather than later-especially with things like student debt and saving for kids' education already weighing on millennials.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Not to mention their student loan debtand the desire to save for their childrens education.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. That daily coffee adds up, but so does peace of mind.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. That daily coffee adds up, but so does peace of mind.
